title: Most recent toxic player: "I hope you die, and your whole family dies...
body:
....and your offspring have autism, and get tortured in a torture camp" 

My sister has quite severe autism coincidentally.

"Rape. Your. Autistic. Sister."

Word for word.

Riot?

replies.body:
Not sure if trolling.

I'm not excusing what that player said, but it's worth noting that whether or not your sister is actually autistic is, frankly, irrelevant.

It's relevant to me because I have first-hand experience with severe autism, and know what a frustratingly hard disability it is to have. Mouthing off about relatives having autism affects me more than it would a normal person because it's being used as though it's a generally accepted insult, when, in actual fact, my sister is beautiful and happy - despite being burdened with the disability. It just hits me in all the wrong places, and mentioning my circumstance highlights the fact that people shouldn't say things to a stranger they know nothing about.

Can you agree with it inflicting extra harm because of my circumstance? My guess is yes. The same way a more sensitive, caring person will be more hurt by abuse than a tough, careless person.

It's not about receiving special treatment, it's about bringing someone to justice who sorely deserves it. Because I've been more affected by it than the average person would be, I feel more of a need to voice the injustice. The same way a sensitive person would feel more of a need to voice the injustice than a tough person. The sensitive person wouldn't be expecting special treatment because they're sensitive, but they'll still voice their opinion more loudly because of the damage inflicted. 

Because abuse can cause harm in a way such as this, voicing the situation highlights the scope of its severity in general. Thus, raising awareness.

I understand fully, but they obviously don't. They have no idea what it is like to experience someone with autism so they are never going to understand and there is no point trying to make them either.

Believe me when I say this but, people want a reason to reject your post because they think you are ignorant to the situation. Ignore them and move on.
What the player said in itself was toxic and morally wrong. It doesn't have to have applied to the victim to be offensive or abusive. It was already abusive from the moment he said it.
Hey look, a smart person.

Because the condition exists, it's always a possibility. If a blind person starts ranting about black people on a train, he won't know if there are black people present. If there are (and there's always a possibility), they'll be more offended and take things to heart more so than other observers. Even though the blind person doesn't know they're there, the extra offense taken by them is, in my opinion, justified.

Similarly, because I'm affected by the impact of the condition, having it mentioned in such a negative context is more impacting - that impact being caused by the aggressor who no doubt is aware that autism exists, and has overlooked the possibility as irrelevant. 

Also, half way through his harassment, he did know. Because I told him I happened to have an autistic sister and found it highly offensive. He replied with "Rape. Your. Autistic. Sister." So not only did he overlook the possibility as irrelevant to begin with, but capitalised on the anomaly to intentionally inflict MORE damage. Showing how intent he was on inflicting harm. Comparably, if a black person spoke up in my example, saying "I'm black and I find this extremely offensive. How dare you?" and having the blind person continue, and personally attack the man who spoke up.

So, let me get this straight. Someone uses autism as an insult and knowing this you tell them that your sister is autistic. You're then surprised when they use that against you. Sorry man, you kind of had it coming. You do remember the whole "sticks and stones" phrase right?

No, not surprised at all. In fact, part of the reason I allowed myself to tell them, knowing the possible consequences, was to test how far they would go to hurt me, and how disrespectful they would be - thus highlighting the malice of the abuser. 

> Sorry man, you kind of had it coming.

I had it coming? You're saying I deserve, or should EXPECT the personal attack because I let them know how hurtful that personal attack is? I disagree. All blame should be on the aggressor, because a normal, civilised person would intentionally AVOID personal attacks (let alone any attacks at all) given the knowledge of it's impact.

> In fact, part of the reason I allowed myself to tell them, knowing the possible consequences, was to test how far they would go to hurt me, and how disrespectful they would be - thus highlighting the malice of the abuser.

> All blame should be on the aggressor, because a normal, civilised person would intentionally AVOID personal attacks (let alone any attacks at all) given the knowledge of it's impact.

A normal, civilised person doesn't go around effectively provoking a response out of someone just so that they can go and complain about it on the forums. You're actually mental.

I said "part of the reason". I was hopeful that it would encourage them to stop. I just knew there was a possibility they wouldn't. That isn't manipulative. Nor is it mental. It wasn't provocative, because I had no way of knowing what would happen. What kind of masochistic person provokes infliction of pain? That's irrational. Don't assume I'm irrational. I'm just aware of the possible consequences of letting them know.
